Published by Elsevier B.V.","name":"copyright","label":"Copyright"}],"article-number":"101427"},{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2023,3,9]],"date-time":"2023-03-09T05:37:39Z","timestamp":1678340259328},"reference-count":0,"publisher":"Nordic Welfare Centre","content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"abstract":"<jats:p>The COVID-19 pandemic has in many ways challenged the health and well-being of people, and more widely, the welfare systems in the Nordic countries. Due to regulations and lockdowns, many people have experienced social isolation, and certain vulnerable groups \u2013 such as older adults and those with disabilities \u2013 have been hit especially hard.As loneliness has implications for people\u2019s long-term mental and physical health, the consequences of the pandemic are significant for health and social care as a whole.This report presents cases of what was done in the Nordic region to alleviate loneliness during the pandemic. The material for this report was collected between June and September 2022. The five Nordic examples show that there are many ways to tackle social isolation and loneliness.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.52746\/ybbz4491","type":"report","created":{"date-parts":[[2023,3,8]],"date-time":"2023-03-08T13:12:21Z","timestamp":1678281141000},"source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":0,"title":["Reducing countries"],"prefix":"10.52746","member":"30447","published-online":{"date-parts":[[2023]]},"deposited":{"date-parts":[[2023,3,8]],"date-time":"2023-03-08T13:12:24Z","timestamp":1678281144000},"score":46.206417,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/nordicwelfare.org\/pub\/Final_Reducing_social_isolation_and_loneliness_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic\/"}},"issued":{"date-parts":[[2023]]},"references-count":0,"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.52746\/ybbz4491","published":{"date-parts":[[2023]]}},{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2022,10,3]],"date-time":"2022-10-03T04:50:45Z","timestamp":1664772645484},"reference-count":0,"publisher":"International J Social Psych"],"published-print":{"date-parts":[[2023,6]]},"abstract":"<jats:title>Abstract<\/jats:title><jats:p>During a pandemic, it is vital to identify factors that motivate individuals to behave in ways that limit virus transmission (i.e., anti\u2010COVID\u201019 behaviour). Fear has been suggested to motivate health\u2010oriented behaviour, yet fear of the virus (i.e., fear of COVID\u201019) could have unintended consequences, such as an increase in anti\u2010immigrant prejudice. In a three\u2010wave longitudinal study (N<jats:sub>T1<\/jats:sub>\u00a0=\u00a04275) in five European countries from April to October 2020, we investigated how social norms, the impact of the pandemic on individuals, and intergroup contact affected fear of COVID\u201019 and\u2014or in turn\u2014anti\u2010COVID\u201019 behaviour and prejudice towards immigrants. A latent change score model\u2014distinguishing between intra\u2010 and inter\u2010individual changes in outcomes\u2014indicated that fear of COVID\u201019 influenced neither anti\u2010COVID\u201019 behaviour nor prejudice. Anti\u2010COVID\u201019 behaviour was increased by anti\u2010COVID\u201019 norms (i.e., belief that others perform anti\u2010COVID\u201019 behaviours), while prejudice was influenced by positive and negative direct and mass\u2010mediated intergroup contact.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.1002\/ejsp.2928","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2022,11,22]],"date-time":"2022-11-22T08:31:07Z","timestamp":1669105867000},"page":"645-663","update-policy":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1002\/crossmark_policy","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":7,"title":["Change
